message_1:
A company wants to segment its customer base into 3 clusters based on their purchase behavior. The company collected data on the number of items purchased by each customer over the past year. Using cluster analysis, determine the center and radius of the clusters. The data is as follows:

Customer #1: bought 10 items
Customer #2: bought 15 items
Customer #3: bought 22 items
Customer #4: bought 7 items
Customer #5: bought 18 items
Customer #6: bought 12 items
Customer #7: bought 25 items
Customer #8: bought 9 items
Customer #9: bought 14 items
Customer #10: bought 17 items
message_2:
To perform cluster analysis, we can use the k-means clustering algorithm. In this case, we have k=3 clusters. The algorithm works as follows:

1. Initialize the cluster centroids randomly by selecting k data points.
2. Assign each data point to the nearest centroid.
3. Update the centroids by calculating the mean of all the data points assigned to each centroid.
4. Repeat steps 2 and 3 until the centroids do not change significantly or a certain number of iterations have been reached.

Let's start by initializing the centroids randomly. We can choose the following data points as initial centroids:

Centroid 1: 10 items (Customer #1)
Centroid 2: 15 items (Customer #2)
Centroid 3: 22 items (Customer #3)

Now, we assign each data point to the nearest centroid and update the centroids:

Cluster 1: 7, 9, 10, 12 (Customers #1, #4, #6, #8)
Cluster 2: 14, 15, 17 (Customers #2, #5, #9, #10)
Cluster 3: 18, 22, 25 (Customers #3, #5, #7)

Update the centroids by calculating the mean of each cluster:

Centroid 1: (7+9+10+12)/4 = 9.5
Centroid 2: (14+15+17)/3 = 15.33
Centroid 3: (18+22+25)/3 = 21.67

Since the centroids have changed, we need to reassign the data points and update the centroids again:

Cluster 1: 7, 9, 10 (Customers #4, #8, #1)
Cluster 2: 12, 14, 15 (Customers #6, #9, #2)
Cluster 3: 17, 18, 22, 25 (Customers #10, #5, #3, #7)

Update the centroids:

Centroid 1: (7+9+10)/3 = 8.67
Centroid 2: (12+14+15)/3 = 13.67
Centroid 3: (17+18+22+25)/4 = 20.5

Reassign the data points:

Cluster 1: 7, 9, 10 (Customers #4, #8, #1)
Cluster 2: 12, 14, 15 (Customers #6, #9, #2)
Cluster 3: 17, 18, 22, 25 (Customers #10, #5, #3, #7)

The centroids have not changed significantly, so we can stop the algorithm.

The final clusters are:

Cluster 1: 7, 9, 10 (Customers #4, #8, #1) with center 8.67
Cluster 2: 12, 14, 15 (Customers #6, #9, #2) with center 13.67
Cluster 3: 17, 18, 22, 25 (Customers #10, #5, #3, #7) with center 20.5

To find the radius of each cluster, we calculate the maximum distance between the center and the data points in each cluster:

Cluster 1 radius: max(|8.67-7|, |8.67-9|, |8.67-10|) = 2.67
Cluster 2 radius: max(|13.67-12|, |13.67-14|, |13.67-15|) = 1.33
Cluster 3 radius: max(|20.5-17|, |20.5-18|, |20.5-22|, |20.5-25|) = 4.5

So, the centers and radii of the clusters are:

Cluster 1: Center 8.67, Radius 2.67
Cluster 2: Center 13.67, Radius 1.33
Cluster 3: Center 20.5, Radius 4.5
